A study published in the Journal of Criminal Justice found that Muslim prisoners were more likely to reoffend than Christian, Buddhist, or Hindu prisoners. A study published in the Journal of Criminal Justice found that Muslim prisoners in the UK were more likely to reoffend than prisoners of other religions, with a reoffending rate of 60% compared to 40% for non-Muslim prisoners. There are several reasons why Muslim prisoners may be more likely to reoffend than prisoners of other religions. One reason is that Islam teaches its followers to prioritize justice and compassion, which can make it more difficult for Muslim prisoners to resist the temptation to reoffend. Finally, the cultural and social norms of Muslim communities may make it more difficult for Muslim prisoners to adjust to life outside of prison, which can increase the likelihood of reoffending.
